THINKING: STEP 1 - DIAGNOSIS CONFIRMATION & SEVERITY ASSESSMENT: - Confidence: Subconjunctival hemorrhage is highly likely given the presentation of eye redness, swelling, tearing, and recent trauma from playing soccer. - Severity: Mild to moderate; typically benign, but extent of hemorrhage and any associated trauma should be assessed. - Urgency: Routine care, unless there are signs of globe rupture, visual changes, or trauma-associated complications. - Differential considerations: Corneal abrasion, trauma-related globe injury, or other ocular injuries; monitor for worsening symptoms.  STEP 2 - EVIDENCE-BASED TREATMENT SELECTION: - First-line treatment: Reassurance and observation; symptomatic management as needed. - Rationale: Self-limited condition, no specific treatment required unless visual disturbance occurs. - Patient considerations: Given the stoic_minimizer demeanor, emphasize the benign nature and importance of monitoring. - Cautions: Watch for signs of expanding hemorrhage or vision changes, which would warrant urgent review.  STEP 3 - PHARMACOLOGICAL INTERVENTIONS: - Medications: None routinely indicated for uncomplicated subconjunctival hemorrhage. - If discomfort occurs: Artificial tears or lubricating eye drops for irritation. - Timeline: Resolution typically occurs within 1-2 weeks. - Monitoring: Ensure no signs of infection or worsening bleeding.  STEP 4 - NON-PHARMACOLOGICAL INTERVENTIONS: - Recommendations: Avoid rubbing the eye, and limit strenuous activity temporarily. - Education: Instruct that it should resolve spontaneously; no need for antibiotics. - Lifestyle modifications: Rest and avoid trauma. - Behavioral: Stress the benign nature to minimize patient anxiety.  STEP 5 - MONITORING & FOLLOW-UP STRATEGY: - Follow-up: Reassess in 1 week if no improvement or sooner if symptoms worsen. - Parameters: Visual acuity changes, globe integrity, symptom progression. - Red flags: Sudden vision loss, pain, associated trauma, or signs of globe rupture. - Response to treatment: Expect resolution; persistence beyond 2 weeks should prompt further evaluation.  STEP 6 - PATIENT COMMUNICATION STRATEGY: - Approach: Provide clear, reassuring information emphasizing the benign and self-limiting nature. - Concerns: Address any worries about vision loss or recurrence proactively. - Adherence: Encourage avoiding eye rubbing and follow-up appointments. - Family: Not necessary unless patient requests support or more education.  STEP 7 - COORDINATION & REFERRALS: - Referrals: No specialist needed unless abnormal findings; consider ophthalmology if visual symptoms or trauma is severe. - Healthcare team: Primary care follow-up for overall health management. - Resources: Provide educational leaflets on eye trauma and signs of complications. - Cost: Ensure the patient understands that outpatient observation is sufficient to minimize unnecessary expenses.
